apart.core.tables — Routing Tables¶

This module models the routing tables used by nodes.

It provides an abstract base class, SqliteRoutingTable, and two concrete classes: RoutingTable and PrevRoutingTable. These two table together form the routing table of the node.

This module also defines the RoutingTableError exception.

exception apart.core.tables.RoutingTableError[source]¶

Bases: Exception

Raised when an invalid operation is performed on the routing tables

class apart.core.tables.PrevRoutingTable(node, network_uid)[source]¶

Bases: apart.core.tables.SqliteRoutingTable

The routing table of nodes that specifies the previous hops associated to each entry of their main routing table.

Each node has a different instance of this class.

This table features rows that describe (possibly multiple) previous hops associated to each route known by a given node. That is, each row in this table refers to a row in the main routing table RoutingTable of the node.

To illustrate the use of this table: when a node receives a message from a neighbor node Y and with circuit identifier cid, it makes a lookup in this table for (PREV_NODE = Y, PREV_CID = cid), which allows to retrieve the ROWID of the associated entry in the main routing table. Consequently, the node makes a lookup in the main routing table (and then possibly relays the message on the specified next hop).

Each entry in the table exhibits the following fields:
  • ROWID (int): the (unique) identifier of the table entry
  • NODE (int): used internally, to differentiate which SQL table entry belongs to which node
  • PREV_NODE (int): the index of the previous node on the route (can be considered as its IP address)
  • PREV_CID (int): the circuit identifier of the previous hop
  • RT_ROWID (int): the ROWID of the RoutingTable entry that this previous hop relates to

Each of these fields can be accessed by PrevRoutingTable.FIELD.

class apart.core.tables.RoutingTable(node, network_uid)[source]¶

Bases: apart.core.tables.SqliteRoutingTable

The main routing table of nodes.

Each node has a different instance of this class.

This table features rows that describe routes that a given node knows. Each entry in the table exhibits the following fields: * ROWID (int): the (unique) identifier of the table entry * NODE (int): used internally, to differentiate which SQL table entry belongs to which node * PSEUDO (int): pseudonym of the end-receiver of the route * CONE (Ctxt): encryption of one used to encrypt/re-encrypt messages on the route * NEXT_NODE (int): index of the next node on the route (can be considered as the next hop’s IP address) * NEXT_CID (int): circuit identifier of the next hop * REPROPOSED (bool): whether the node relayed this route to its neighbor. Used in the route proposal policy. * IN_USE (bool): True if the node uses this route as end-sender, False if it uses it only as relay. * TIMESTAMP (int): time at which the routing table entry was created * ACTUAL_RCVR (int): index of the end-receiver of the route. used only for debug and statistics purposes. * ACTUAL_LENGTH (int): number of hops between the node and the end-receiver of the route. Used only for debug and statistics purposes

Each of these fields can be accessed by RoutingTable.FIELD.

class apart.core.tables.SqliteRoutingTable(node, network_uid)[source]¶

Bases: object

Abstract base class for routing tables.

Manages the tables in an in-memory sqlite3 database. Creates one table per type of routing table, but all nodes use the same sql database and tables.

insert_entries(entries)[source]¶

Insert several routing table entries.

Parameters:entries (list of dict str->any) – a list of dict adequate for input to insert_entry()
Raises:RoutingTableError – if at least one of the entries specified in argument does not match the fields of the considered table
insert_entry(**kwargs)[source]¶

Insert a routing table entry

The arguments of this function depend on the concrete routing table that on which this function is called. This function checks that the **kwargs in argument specifies all the fields of the said routing table (in accordance with the static _fields member of the class that defines the routing table, see RoutingTable and PrevRoutingTable for a description of those fields)).

Parameters:**kwargs (dict str->any) – the dict specifying the entry to insert. This dict is indexed by the fields of the routing table, and must specify a value for all of them.
Returns:the (unique) id of the new entry
Return type:int
Raises:RoutingTableError – if the entry specified in input does not match the fields of the considered table
joint_lookup(other_table, fields=None, join_on=None, constraints=None, constraints_bindings=None, order_by=None)[source]¶

Perform mode advanced lookups, involving a SQL JOIN

This function is often used by nodes to perform a lookup on a previous hop (in table PrevRoutingTable), joined on the corresponding entry of the table RoutingTable. This avoids doing two SQL queries. See PrevRoutingTable for more details.

Parameters:
  • other_table (RoutingTable or PrevRoutingTable) – the table to join on the first (the first being the one on which this function is called)
  • fields (list of string, optional) – see lookup() (Default: None)
  • join_on (2-tuple of str, optional) – the field of each of the rwo routing tables on which to perform the join (Default: None)
  • constraints (string or dict of str->any, optional) – see lookup() (Default: None)
  • constraints_bindings (list of any) – see lookup() (Default: None)
  • order_by (list of str) – see lookup() (Default: None)
Returns:

the list of routing table entries returned according to the constraints of the lookup
Return type:

(list of sqlite3.Row)
lookup(fields=None, constraints=None, constraints_bindings=None, order_by=None)[source]¶

Lookup one or several routing table entries

Parameters:
  • fields (list of string, optional) – the table fields that must be returned by the lookup (Default: None)
  • constraints (string or dict, optional) – the constraints of the lookup. Can either be a string containing text suitable for a WHERE SQL clause, with ‘?’ in place of values; either a dict that maps a field to a value. In the latter case, the WHERE clause is constructed as a conjunction of the constrain on each field in the dict. (Default: None)
  • consraints_bindings (list of any) – if constraints is provided as a string (a SQL-like WHERE clause), then the values in this argument are used as bindings for the ‘?’ place holders in constraints
  • order_by (list of str) – list of fields, specifying the order in
  • results should be provided (which) –
Returns:

the list of routing table entries returned according to the constraints of the lookup
Return type:

(list of sqlite3.Row)

Remove entries from a routing table that fit into the specified constraints.

  • constraints (string or dict of str->any, optional) – see lookup() (Default: None)
  • constraints_bindings (list of any) – see lookup() (Default: None)
